dn30:0.2.eng: The Marks of a Great Man

dn30:1.1.1.comm: The marks of the “five great men” are discussed in the later astrological text, Bṛhatsaṃhitā 69.

dn30:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
dn30:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

dn30:1.1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

dn30:1.1.7.pli: “Dvattiṃsimāni, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
dn30:1.1.7.eng: “There are thirty-two marks of a great man. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
dn30:1.1.7.comm: This is one of the latest suttas in the Pali Nikāyas. Typically this topic only comes up in relation to the Buddha’s fulfillment of Brahmanical prophecies. Here it is developed with a series of ornate verses, none of which have parallels. Nonetheless, it is worth noting that nowhere in the extensive discussions of the Buddha’s past good deeds is there any mention of the later concepts of the pāramīs (“perfections”) or the Bodhisatta path.

dn30:1.1.8.pli: Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
dn30:1.1.8.eng: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.

dn30:1.1.9.eng: He has the following seven treasures:

dn30:1.1.10.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—cakkaratanaṃ hatthiratanaṃ assaratanaṃ maṇiratanaṃ itthiratanaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.
dn30:1.1.10.eng: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.

dn30:1.1.11.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
dn30:1.1.11.eng: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

dn30:1.1.12.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
dn30:1.1.12.eng: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

dn30:1.1.13.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
dn30:1.1.13.eng: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who has cast off the world’s veil.

dn30:1.2.1.pli: Katamāni ca tāni, bhikkhave, dvattiṃsa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā?
dn30:1.2.1.eng: And what are the thirty-two marks?
dn30:1.2.1.comm: The marks are elsewhere listed in DN 14:1.32.7 and MN 91:9.1. I discuss the translation of the marks in my comments to DN 14.

dn30:1.2.2.pli: Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…

dn30:1.2.3.pli: sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.

dn30:1.2.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso suppatiṭṭhitapādo hoti. Yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso suppatiṭṭhitapādo hoti, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.

dn30:1.2.5.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni honti sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni. Yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni honti sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.
dn30:1.2.5.eng: On the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail.

dn30:1.2.6.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso āyatapaṇhi hoti …pe…

dn30:1.2.8.eng: His hands and feet are tender.

dn30:1.2.9.eng: He has serried hands and feet.

dn30:1.2.10.eng: The tops of his feet are arched.

dn30:1.2.11.eng: His calves are like those of an antelope.

dn30:1.2.12.pli: ṭhitakova anonamanto ubhohi pāṇitalehi jaṇṇukāni parimasati parimajjati …
dn30:1.2.12.eng: When standing upright and not bending over, the palms of both hands touch the knees.

dn30:1.2.13.eng: His private parts are covered in a foreskin.

dn30:1.2.14.eng: He is golden colored; his skin shines like lustrous gold.

dn30:1.2.15.pli: sukhumacchavi hoti, sukhumattā chaviyā rajojallaṃ kāye na upalimpati …
dn30:1.2.15.eng: He has delicate skin, so delicate that dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.

dn30:1.2.16.pli: ekekalomo hoti, ekekāni lomāni lomakūpesu jātāni …
dn30:1.2.16.eng: His hairs grow one per pore.

dn30:1.2.17.pli: uddhaggalomo hoti, uddhaggāni lomāni jātāni nīlāni añjanavaṇṇāni kuṇḍalāvaṭṭāni dakkhiṇāvaṭṭakajātāni …
dn30:1.2.17.eng: His hairs stand up; they’re blue-black and curl clockwise.

dn30:1.2.18.eng: His body is tall and straight-limbed.

dn30:1.2.19.eng: He has bulging muscles in seven places.

dn30:1.2.20.eng: His chest is like that of a lion.

dn30:1.2.21.eng: He is filled out between the shoulders.

dn30:1.2.22.pli: nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo hoti, yāvatakvassa kāyo tāvatakvassa byāmo yāvatakvassa byāmo tāvatakvassa kāyo …
dn30:1.2.22.eng: He has the proportional circumference of a banyan tree: the span of his arms equals the height of his body.

dn30:1.2.25.eng: His jaw is like that of a lion.

dn30:1.2.31.eng: He has the voice of the Divinity, <j>like a cuckoo’s call.

dn30:1.2.33.eng: He has eyelashes like a cow’s.

dn30:1.2.34.pli: uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā hoti, odātā mudutūlasannibhā. Yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa uṇṇā bhamukantare jātā hoti, odātā mudutūlasannibhā, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.
dn30:1.2.34.eng: Between his eyebrows there grows a tuft, soft and white like cotton-wool.

dn30:1.2.35.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso uṇhīsasīso hoti. Yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso uṇhīsasīso hoti, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ bhavati.
dn30:1.2.35.eng: The crown of his head is like a turban.

dn30:1.3.1.pli: Imāni kho tāni, bhikkhave, dvattiṃsa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
dn30:1.3.1.eng: These are the thirty-two marks of a great man. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.

dn30:1.3.2.pli: Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…

dn30:1.3.3.pli: sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.

dn30:1.3.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, dvattiṃsa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni bāhirakāpi isayo dhārenti, no ca kho te jānanti:
dn30:1.3.4.eng: Seers who are outsiders remember these marks, but they do not know

dn30:1.3.5.eng: the specific deeds performed in the past to obtain each mark.
dn30:1.3.5.comm: The later astrological texts such as the Gārgīyajyotiṣa and Bṛhatsaṁhitā that discuss similar marks are more concerned with how they indicate character and destiny than their moral causes.

dn30:1.4.1.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno daḷhasamādāno ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, avatthitasamādāno kāyasucarite vacīsucarite manosucarite dānasaṃvibhāge sīlasamādāne uposathupavāse matteyyatāya petteyyatāya sāmaññatāya brahmaññatāya kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitāya aññataraññataresu ca adhikusalesu dhammesu.
dn30:1.4.1.eng: In some past lives, past existences, past abodes the Realized One was reborn as a human being. He firmly and persistently undertook skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.
dn30:1.4.1.comm: The key terms here are daḷha (“firm”) and avatthita (“persistently”), which result in his firm stance.

dn30:1.4.2.pli: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
dn30:1.4.2.eng: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.4.3.pli: So tattha aññe deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhiggaṇhāti dibbena āyunā dibbena vaṇṇena dibbena sukhena dibbena yasena dibbena ādhipateyyena dibbehi rūpehi dibbehi saddehi dibbehi gandhehi dibbehi rasehi dibbehi phoṭṭhabbehi.
dn30:1.4.3.eng: There he surpassed the other gods in ten respects: heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

dn30:1.4.4.pli: So tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.4.4.eng: When he passed away from there and came back to this place he obtained this mark of a great man:

dn30:1.4.6.pli: Samaṃ pādaṃ bhūmiyaṃ nikkhipati, samaṃ uddharati, samaṃ sabbāvantehi pādatalehi bhūmiṃ phusati.
dn30:1.4.6.eng: He places his foot on the ground evenly, raises it evenly, and touches the ground evenly with the whole sole of his foot.

dn30:1.5.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
dn30:1.5.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.5.2.eng: He has the following seven treasures:

dn30:1.5.3.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—cakkaratanaṃ hatthiratanaṃ assaratanaṃ maṇiratanaṃ itthiratanaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.
dn30:1.5.3.eng: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.

dn30:1.5.4.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
dn30:1.5.4.eng: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

dn30:1.5.5.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṃ iddhaṃ phītaṃ khemaṃ sivaṃ nirabbudaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
dn30:1.5.5.eng: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, free of pests—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
dn30:1.5.5.comm: The commentary explain akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṁ as “free of bandits” (niccoraṁ). Bandits are also regarded as “pests” (abbuda, literally “tumor” or “cancer”) at SN 1.77:3.4.

dn30:1.5.6.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.5.7.pli: Akkhambhiyo hoti kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena paccāmittena.
dn30:1.5.7.eng: He can’t be stopped by any human foe or enemy.

dn30:1.5.8.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.5.9.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
dn30:1.5.9.eng: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who has cast off the world’s veil.

dn30:1.5.10.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.5.11.pli: Akkhambhiyo hoti abbhantarehi vā bāhirehi vā paccatthikehi paccāmittehi rāgena vā dosena vā mohena vā samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
dn30:1.5.11.eng: He can’t be stopped by any foe or enemy whether internal or external; nor by greed, hate, or delusion; nor by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

dn30:1.5.12.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.6.5.eng: firmly undertaking these things, he lived accordingly.

dn30:1.7.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.7.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.7.2.pli: bahujanassa sukhāvaho ahosi, ubbegauttāsabhayaṃ apanuditā, dhammikañca rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidhātā, saparivārañca dānaṃ adāsi.
dn30:1.7.2.eng: He conveyed happiness to many people, casting out threats, terror, and danger, providing just protection and security, and giving gifts with all the trimmings.
dn30:1.7.2.comm: He “conveyed happiness” (sukhāvaho), like a wheeled cart would convey goods. | Parivāra means “surroundings, accompaniments”, and I follow the commentary, which takes it in the sense of the “trimmings” accompanying the food. Given, however, that the kammic result is a large parivāra (“following”), it might mean that he gave not just physical things, but was generous with his followers also, engaging them in such beneficial tasks.

dn30:1.7.3.pli: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati …pe…
dn30:1.7.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.7.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.7.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:

dn30:1.7.5.pli: Heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni honti sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni suvibhattantarāni.
dn30:1.7.5.eng: on the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail and well divided inside.

dn30:1.8.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.8.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.8.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.8.4.eng: of brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

dn30:1.8.5.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.8.6.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
dn30:1.8.6.eng: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a fully awakened Buddha.

dn30:1.8.7.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.8.9.pli: mahāssa honti parivārā bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā.
dn30:1.8.9.eng: of monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:1.8.10.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.9.3.eng: he brought happiness to many people,

dn30:1.9.4.eng: ridding them of fear, terror, and danger,

dn30:1.9.6.eng: By means of these deeds he went to heaven,

dn30:1.9.7.eng: where he enjoyed happiness and merriment.

dn30:1.9.8.eng: After passing away from there to here,

dn30:1.9.9.eng: wheels on his two feet are found,

dn30:1.9.12.eng: seeing the prince <j>with the hundred-fold mark of merits,
dn30:1.9.12.comm: This refers to the late legend of the soothsayers seeing the baby Siddhattha, and as such kumāra should be taken as “prince”.

dn30:1.9.13.eng: that he’d have a following, subduing foes,

dn30:1.9.14.eng: which is why he has wheels all rimmed around.

dn30:1.9.15.eng: If one such doesn’t choose the life gone forth,

dn30:1.9.16.eng: he’ll roll the wheel and rule the land.

dn30:1.9.17.eng: The aristocrats will be his vassals,

dn30:1.9.19.eng: But if one such chooses the life gone forth,

dn30:1.9.21.eng: the gods, humans, titans, Sakka, and monsters;

dn30:1.9.22.eng: centaurs and dragons, birds and beasts,

dn30:1.9.24.eng: the supreme, honored by gods and humans.”

dn30:1.10.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.10.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.10.2.pli: pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato ahosi nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī vihāsi.
dn30:1.10.2.eng: He gave up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. He was scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.

dn30:1.10.3.pli: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā …pe…
dn30:1.10.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.10.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni tīṇi mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.10.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these three marks:

dn30:1.10.5.pli: Āyatapaṇhi ca hoti, dīghaṅguli ca brahmujugatto ca.
dn30:1.10.5.eng: he has stretched heels, long fingers, and his body is tall and straight-limbed.
dn30:1.10.5.comm: Giving up killing results in long life. This seems to be applied by metaphor to having these long and elegant body parts.

dn30:1.11.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.11.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.11.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.11.3.pli: Dīghāyuko hoti ciraṭṭhitiko, dīghamāyuṃ pāleti, na sakkā hoti antarā jīvitā voropetuṃ kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena paccāmittena.
dn30:1.11.3.eng: He’s long-lived, preserving his life for a long time. No human foe or enemy is able to take his life before his time.

dn30:1.11.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.11.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.11.6.pli: Dīghāyuko hoti ciraṭṭhitiko, dīghamāyuṃ pāleti, na sakkā hoti antarā jīvitā voropetuṃ paccatthikehi paccāmittehi samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
dn30:1.11.6.eng: He’s long-lived, preserving his life for a long time. No foes or enemies—nor any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or anyone in the world—is able to take his life before his time.

dn30:1.11.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.12.2.eng: “Realizing for himself the horrors of death,

dn30:1.12.3.eng: he refrained from killing other creatures.

dn30:1.12.4.eng: By that good conduct he went to heaven,

dn30:1.12.5.eng: where he enjoyed the fruit of deeds well done.

dn30:1.12.6.eng: Passing away, on his return to here,

dn30:1.12.8.eng: his stretched heels are abundant and long,

dn30:1.12.9.eng: and like the Divinity, he’s straight and beautiful, <j>with well-formed limbs.
dn30:1.12.9.comm: Whereas in the phrase brahmujugatto, brahm- means “extended, tall”, here brahmāva means “like Brahmā”, either as a play on words or by mistaken etymology.

dn30:1.12.10.eng: Fair of arm, youthful, of good posture and breeding,

dn30:1.12.11.eng: his fingers are soft and tender and long.

dn30:1.12.12.eng: By these three marks of an excellent man,

dn30:1.12.13.eng: they indicated that the prince’s life would be long:

dn30:1.12.14.eng: ‘As a householder he will live long;
dn30:1.12.14.comm: This verse spoken by the soothsayers.

dn30:1.12.15.eng: longer still if he goes forth, due to

dn30:1.12.16.eng: mastery in the development of psychic power.

dn30:1.12.17.eng: Thus this is the sign of long life.’”

dn30:1.13.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.13.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.13.2.pli: dātā ahosi paṇītānaṃ rasitānaṃ khādanīyānaṃ bhojanīyānaṃ sāyanīyānaṃ lehanīyānaṃ pānānaṃ.
dn30:1.13.2.eng: He was a donor of delicious and tasty cooked and fresh foods, and drinks that were sweet and succulent.
dn30:1.13.2.comm: He receives bodily fullness as a result of giving food.

dn30:1.13.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.13.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati, sattussado hoti, sattassa ussadā honti;
dn30:1.13.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark: he has bulging muscles in seven places.

dn30:1.13.5.pli: ubhosu hatthesu ussadā honti, ubhosu pādesu ussadā honti, ubhosu aṃsakūṭesu ussadā honti, khandhe ussado hoti.
dn30:1.13.5.eng: Both hands, both feet, both shoulders, and his chest are all bulging.

dn30:1.14.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.14.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.14.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.14.3.pli: Lābhī hoti paṇītānaṃ rasitānaṃ khādanīyānaṃ bhojanīyānaṃ sāyanīyānaṃ lehanīyānaṃ pānānaṃ.
dn30:1.14.3.eng: He gets delicious and tasty cooked and fresh foods, and drinks that are sweet and succulent.

dn30:1.14.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.14.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.14.6.pli: Lābhī hoti paṇītānaṃ rasitānaṃ khādanīyānaṃ bhojanīyānaṃ sāyanīyānaṃ lehanīyānaṃ pānānaṃ.
dn30:1.14.6.eng: He gets delicious and tasty cooked and fresh foods, and drinks that are sweet and succulent.

dn30:1.14.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.15.2.eng: “He used to give the very best of flavors—

dn30:1.15.5.eng: he rejoiced long in the Garden of Delight.
dn30:1.15.5.comm: Nandana, the celestial garden in the realm of the Thirty-Three.

dn30:1.15.6.eng: On returning to here, he is rounded in seven places,

dn30:1.15.7.eng: and tender hands and feet are found.

dn30:1.15.8.eng: The soothsayers expert in signs declared:

dn30:1.15.9.eng: ‘He’ll get tasty foods of all sorts

dn30:1.15.10.eng: as a householder, that’s what that means.

dn30:1.15.11.eng: But even if he goes forth he’ll get the same,

dn30:1.15.12.eng: supreme in gaining tasty foods of all sorts,

dn30:1.15.13.eng: cutting all bonds of the lay life.’”

dn30:1.16.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.16.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.16.2.eng: He brought people together using the four ways of being inclusive:

dn30:1.16.3.eng: giving, kindly words, taking care, and equality.

dn30:1.16.4.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.16.5.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.16.5.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:

dn30:1.16.6.eng: his hands and feet are tender, and they are serried.
dn30:1.16.6.comm: “Tender” because he treated people tenderly; “serried” because his fingers and toes are kept gracefully together, not splayed and separated.

dn30:1.17.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.17.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.17.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.17.3.pli: Susaṅgahitaparijano hoti, susaṅgahitāssa honti brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
dn30:1.17.3.eng: His retinue is inclusive, cohesive, and well-managed. This includes brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.
dn30:1.17.3.comm: “Inclusive and well-managed” renders saṅgahita. It means “included”, as in those people who, due to the kindly actions, feel that they belong. For the sense “well-managed” see AN 8.49:2.3. Because of acting kindly and inclusively, people are well-disposed and work well together.

dn30:1.17.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.17.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.17.6.pli: Susaṅgahitaparijano hoti, susaṅgahitāssa honti bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā.
dn30:1.17.6.eng: His retinue is inclusive and well-managed. This includes monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:1.17.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.18.4.eng: such action and conduct as brought people together,

dn30:1.18.5.eng: he went to heaven due to his esteemed virtue.

dn30:1.18.6.eng: Passing away, on his return to here,

dn30:1.18.8.eng: hands and feet so tender and serried,

dn30:1.18.10.eng: His retinue is loyal and manageable,

dn30:1.18.11.eng: staying agreeably all over this broad land.
dn30:1.18.11.comm: Even though the community is geographically dispersed, it is still coherent.

dn30:1.18.14.eng: But if he gives up all sensual enjoyments,

dn30:1.18.15.eng: as victor he speaks Dhamma to the people.

dn30:1.18.16.eng: Devoted, they respond to his words;

dn30:1.18.17.eng: after listening, they practice in line with the teaching.”

dn30:1.19.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.19.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.19.2.pli: atthūpasaṃhitaṃ dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā ahosi, bahujanaṃ nidaṃsesi, pāṇīnaṃ hitasukhāvaho dhammayāgī.
dn30:1.19.2.eng: His speech was meaningful and principled. He educated many people, bringing welfare and happiness, offering the teaching.

dn30:1.19.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.19.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.19.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:

dn30:1.19.5.eng: the tops of his feet are arched and his hairs stand up.
dn30:1.19.5.comm: Perhaps the uprightness of these marks relates to his speech being beneficial, leading upwards.

dn30:1.20.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato, sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.20.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.20.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.20.3.pli: Aggo ca hoti seṭṭho ca pāmokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca kāmabhogīnaṃ.
dn30:1.20.3.eng: He is the foremost, best, chief, highest, and finest of those who enjoy sensual pleasures.

dn30:1.20.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.20.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.20.6.pli: Aggo ca hoti seṭṭho ca pāmokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca sabbasattānaṃ.
dn30:1.20.6.eng: He is the foremost, best, chief, highest, and finest of all sentient beings.

dn30:1.20.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.21.3.eng: moving the people with his explanations.

dn30:1.21.4.eng: He brought welfare and happiness to creatures,

dn30:1.21.7.eng: he advanced to heaven and there rejoiced.

dn30:1.21.8.eng: On return to here two marks are found,

dn30:1.21.12.eng: Swollen with flesh and blood, encased in skin,

dn30:1.21.14.eng: If that sort lives in the home, he becomes

dn30:1.21.15.eng: the best of those who enjoy sensual pleasures.

dn30:1.21.16.eng: There’ll be none better than him;

dn30:1.21.17.eng: he’ll proceed <j>having mastered all the Black Plum Tree Land.

dn30:1.21.18.eng: But going forth the peerless renunciate

dn30:1.21.19.eng: turns into the best of all creatures.

dn30:1.21.20.eng: There’ll be none better than him,

dn30:1.21.21.eng: he’ll live having mastered the whole world.”

dn30:1.22.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.22.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.22.2.pli: sakkaccaṃ vācetā ahosi sippaṃ vā vijjaṃ vā caraṇaṃ vā kammaṃ vā:
dn30:1.22.2.eng: He was a thorough teacher of a profession, a branch of knowledge, conduct, or action, thinking:

dn30:1.22.3.pli: ‘kintime khippaṃ vijāneyyuṃ, khippaṃ paṭipajjeyyuṃ, na ciraṃ kilisseyyun’”ti.
dn30:1.22.3.eng: ‘How might they quickly learn and practice, without getting exhausted?’

dn30:1.22.4.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.22.5.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.22.5.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:

dn30:1.22.6.eng: his calves are like those of an antelope.
dn30:1.22.6.comm: It seems that his “swift” teaching techniques evoke the antelope.

dn30:1.23.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.23.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.23.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.23.3.pli: Yāni tāni rājārahāni rājaṅgāni rājūpabhogāni rājānucchavikāni tāni khippaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.23.3.eng: He quickly obtains the things worthy of a king, the factors, supports, and things befitting a king.

dn30:1.23.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.23.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.23.6.pli: Yāni tāni samaṇārahāni samaṇaṅgāni samaṇūpabhogāni samaṇānucchavikāni, tāni khippaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.23.6.eng: He quickly obtains the things worthy of an ascetic, the factors, supports, and things befitting an ascetic.

dn30:1.23.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.24.3.eng: he thought of how they might easily learn.

dn30:1.24.5.eng: he taught them things that harm no-one at all.

dn30:1.24.6.eng: Having done that skillful deed <j>whose outcome is happiness,

dn30:1.24.7.eng: he gains prominent and elegant calves.

dn30:1.24.9.eng: he’s covered in delicate rising hairs.

dn30:1.24.10.eng: They say that individual has antelope calves,

dn30:1.24.11.eng: and that this is the mark of swift success.

dn30:1.24.12.eng: If he desires the things fitting the household life,

dn30:1.24.13.eng: not going forth, they’ll quickly be his.

dn30:1.24.14.eng: But if one such chooses the life gone forth,

dn30:1.24.16.eng: the peerless renunciate will quickly find

dn30:1.25.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.25.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.25.2.pli: samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā paripucchitā ahosi:
dn30:1.25.2.eng: He approached an ascetic or brahmin and asked:

dn30:1.25.3.pli: ‘kiṃ, bhante, kusalaṃ, kiṃ akusalaṃ, kiṃ sāvajjaṃ, kiṃ anavajjaṃ, kiṃ sevitabbaṃ, kiṃ na sevitabbaṃ, kiṃ me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya assa, kiṃ vā pana me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya assā’ti.
dn30:1.25.3.eng: ‘Sirs, what is skillful? What is unskillful? What is blameworthy? What is blameless? What should be cultivated? What should not be cultivated? Doing what leads to my lasting harm and suffering? Doing what leads to my lasting welfare and happiness?’

dn30:1.25.4.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.25.5.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.25.5.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:

dn30:1.25.6.pli: Sukhumacchavi hoti, sukhumattā chaviyā rajojallaṃ kāye na upalimpati.
dn30:1.25.6.eng: he has delicate skin, so delicate that dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.
dn30:1.25.6.comm: Asking questions leads to wisdom, and the mind of wisdom does not get attached.

dn30:1.26.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.26.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.26.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.26.3.pli: Mahāpañño hoti, nāssa hoti koci paññāya sadiso vā seṭṭho vā kāmabhogīnaṃ.
dn30:1.26.3.eng: He has great wisdom. Of those who enjoy sensual pleasures, none is his equal or better in wisdom.

dn30:1.26.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.26.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.26.6.pli: Mahāpañño hoti puthupañño hāsapañño javanapañño tikkhapañño nibbedhikapañño, nāssa hoti koci paññāya sadiso vā seṭṭho vā sabbasattānaṃ.
dn30:1.26.6.eng: He has great wisdom, widespread wisdom, laughing wisdom, swift wisdom, sharp wisdom, and penetrating wisdom. No sentient being is his equal or better in wisdom.

dn30:1.26.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.27.3.eng: eager to understand, he asked questions.

dn30:1.27.4.eng: Keen to learn, he waited on renunciates,

dn30:1.27.5.eng: heeding their explanation with pure intent.

dn30:1.27.6.eng: Due to that deed of acquiring wisdom,

dn30:1.27.7.eng: as a human being his skin is delicate.

dn30:1.27.8.eng: At his birth <j>the soothsayers expert in signs prophesied:

dn30:1.27.10.eng: If one such doesn’t choose the life gone forth,

dn30:1.27.11.eng: he’ll roll the wheel and rule the land.

dn30:1.27.12.eng: Among those with material things <j>who have been educated,

dn30:1.27.13.pli: Na tena seyyo sadiso ca vijjati.
dn30:1.27.13.eng: none equal or better than him is found.

dn30:1.27.14.eng: But if one such chooses the life gone forth,

dn30:1.27.16.eng: gaining wisdom that’s supreme and distinguished,

dn30:1.27.17.eng: the one of superb, vast intelligence <j>attains awakening.”

dn30:1.28.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.28.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.28.3.pli: bahumpi vutto samāno nābhisajji na kuppi na byāpajji na patitthīyi, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
dn30:1.28.3.eng: Even when heavily criticized he didn’t lose his temper, become annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

dn30:1.28.4.pli: Dātā ca ahosi sukhumānaṃ mudukānaṃ attharaṇānaṃ pāvuraṇānaṃ khomasukhumānaṃ kappāsikasukhumānaṃ koseyyasukhumānaṃ kambalasukhumānaṃ.
dn30:1.28.4.eng: He donated soft and delicate mats and blankets, and delicate cloths of linen, cotton, silk, and wool.

dn30:1.28.5.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.28.6.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn30:1.28.6.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:

dn30:1.28.7.eng: he is golden colored; his skin shines like lustrous gold.
dn30:1.28.7.comm: Giving fine coverings leads to fine skin. Less obviously, anger is said to lead to discoloring and ugliness.

dn30:1.29.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.29.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.29.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.29.3.pli: Lābhī hoti sukhumānaṃ mudukānaṃ attharaṇānaṃ pāvuraṇānaṃ khomasukhumānaṃ kappāsikasukhumānaṃ koseyyasukhumānaṃ kambalasukhumānaṃ.
dn30:1.29.3.eng: He obtains soft and delicate mats and blankets, and delicate cloths of linen, cotton, silk, and wool.

dn30:1.29.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.29.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.29.6.pli: Lābhī hoti sukhumānaṃ mudukānaṃ attharaṇānaṃ pāvuraṇānaṃ khomasukhumānaṃ kappāsikasukhumānaṃ koseyyasukhumānaṃ kambalasukhumānaṃ.
dn30:1.29.6.eng: He obtains soft and delicate mats and blankets, and delicate cloths of linen, cotton, silk, and wool.

dn30:1.29.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.30.2.eng: “Fixated on good will, he gave gifts.
dn30:1.30.2.comm: For this positive sense of adhiṭṭhahi compare AN 6.52:8.2 and MN 140:11.1.

dn30:1.30.3.eng: In an earlier life he poured forth cloth

dn30:1.30.5.eng: like a god pouring rain on this broad earth.
dn30:1.30.5.comm: There’s a play on abhivissaji (“gave away”) and abhivassa (“pouring rain”).

dn30:1.30.6.eng: So doing he passed from here to heaven,

dn30:1.30.7.eng: where he enjoyed the fruits of deeds well done.

dn30:1.30.8.eng: Here he wins a figure shining like honey-yellow gold,
dn30:1.30.8.comm: Kanaka, one of the many Indic words for gold, is from the same Proto-Indo European root as the English word “honey”.

dn30:1.30.9.eng: like Indra, the finest of gods.

dn30:1.30.10.eng: If that man stays in the house, not wishing to go forth,

dn30:1.30.11.eng: he conquers and rules this vast, broad earth.

dn30:1.30.13.eng: so delicate and soft to touch.

dn30:1.30.14.eng: He receives robes, cloth, and the finest garments
dn30:1.30.14.comm: Here mokkha = pāmokkha (“chief, best”).

dn30:1.30.15.eng: if he chooses the life gone forth.

dn30:1.30.16.eng: For he still partakes of past deed’s fruit;

dn30:1.30.17.eng: what’s been done is never lost.”

dn30:1.31.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:1.31.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:1.31.2.pli: cirappanaṭṭhe sucirappavāsino ñātimitte suhajje sakhino samānetā ahosi.
dn30:1.31.2.eng: He reunited long-lost and long-separated relatives, friends, loved ones, and comrades.

dn30:1.31.3.pli: Mātarampi puttena samānetā ahosi, puttampi mātarā samānetā ahosi, pitarampi puttena samānetā ahosi, puttampi pitarā samānetā ahosi, bhātarampi bhātarā samānetā ahosi, bhātarampi bhaginiyā samānetā ahosi, bhaginimpi bhātarā samānetā ahosi, bhaginimpi bhaginiyā samānetā ahosi, samaṅgīkatvā ca abbhanumoditā ahosi.
dn30:1.31.3.eng: He reunited mother with child and child with mother; father with child and child with father; brother with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and sister with sister, bringing them together with rejoicing.

dn30:1.31.4.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:1.31.5.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati—
dn30:1.31.5.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:

dn30:1.31.6.eng: his private parts are covered in a foreskin.
dn30:1.31.6.comm: The penis is the generative organ and hence part-creator of family. Being covered suggests that his sexuality was moderated and contained. His role was more than having children, it was building family.

dn30:1.32.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:1.32.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:1.32.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:1.32.3.pli: Pahūtaputto hoti, parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
dn30:1.32.3.eng: He has many sons, over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

dn30:1.32.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:1.32.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:1.32.6.pli: Pahūtaputto hoti, anekasahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
dn30:1.32.6.eng: He has many sons, many thousands of sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

dn30:1.32.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:1.33.6.eng: By means of these deeds he went to heaven,

dn30:1.33.7.eng: where he enjoyed happiness and merriment.

dn30:1.33.8.eng: After passing away from there to here,

dn30:1.33.9.eng: his private parts are covered in a foreskin.

dn30:1.33.14.eng: But if he lives the renunciate life

dn30:1.33.15.eng: he has even more sons following his word.

dn30:1.33.17.eng: that’s the meaning shown by this mark.”

dn30:1.33.18.eng: The first recitation section is finished.

dn30:2.1.0.eng: 15–16. Equal Proportions and Touching the Knees

dn30:2.1.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.1.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.1.2.pli: mahājanasaṅgahaṃ samekkhamāno samaṃ jānāti sāmaṃ jānāti, purisaṃ jānāti purisavisesaṃ jānāti:
dn30:2.1.2.eng: Examining the gathered population, he knew what they had in common and what was their own; he knew each person, and he knew the distinctions between people.

dn30:2.1.3.eng: In each case, he made appropriate distinctions between people: ‘This one deserves that; that one deserves this.’

dn30:2.1.4.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.1.5.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:2.1.5.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:

dn30:2.1.6.pli: Nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo ca hoti, ṭhitakoyeva ca anonamanto ubhohi pāṇitalehi jaṇṇukāni parimasati parimajjati.
dn30:2.1.6.eng: he has the proportional circumference of a banyan tree; and when standing upright and not bending over, the palms of both hands touch the knees.
dn30:2.1.6.comm: The banyan tree is not just proportioned, it offers shelter to many creatures. Touching the knees indicates connecting with the manyfolk, who at AN 5.196:3.1 are likened to caterpillars reaching the knees.

dn30:2.2.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.2.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.2.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.2.3.pli: Aḍḍho hoti mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro.
dn30:2.2.3.eng: He is rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, lots of money and grain, and a full treasury and storehouses.

dn30:2.2.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.2.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.2.6.eng: He is rich, affluent, and wealthy.

dn30:2.2.7.eng: He has these kinds of wealth:

dn30:2.2.8.pli: saddhādhanaṃ sīladhanaṃ hiridhanaṃ ottappadhanaṃ sutadhanaṃ cāgadhanaṃ paññādhanaṃ.
dn30:2.2.8.eng: the wealth of faith, ethics, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

dn30:2.2.9.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.3.2.eng: “Examining the many people in a community,

dn30:2.3.3.eng: he weighed, evaluated, and judged each case:

dn30:2.3.5.eng: That’s how he used to draw <j>distinctions between people.

dn30:2.3.7.eng: he can touch his knees with both hands.

dn30:2.3.8.eng: With the remaining ripening <j>of the fruit of good deeds,

dn30:2.3.9.eng: his circumference was that of a great tree.

dn30:2.3.10.eng: Learned experts in the many different

dn30:2.3.13.eng: many different things that householders deserve.

dn30:2.3.14.eng: Here there are many suitable pleasures

dn30:2.3.15.eng: for the ruler of the land to enjoy as householder.

dn30:2.3.16.eng: But if he gives up all sensual enjoyments,

dn30:2.3.17.eng: he will gain the supreme, highest peak of wealth.’”

dn30:2.4.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.4.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.4.2.pli: bahujanassa atthakāmo ahosi hitakāmo phāsukāmo yogakkhemakāmo:
dn30:2.4.2.eng: He wanted what’s best, the welfare, the comfort, and sanctuary of the people, thinking:

dn30:2.4.3.pli: ‘kintime saddhāya vaḍḍheyyuṃ, sīlena vaḍḍheyyuṃ, sutena vaḍḍheyyuṃ, cāgena vaḍḍheyyuṃ, dhammena vaḍḍheyyuṃ, paññāya vaḍḍheyyuṃ, dhanadhaññena vaḍḍheyyuṃ, khettavatthunā vaḍḍheyyuṃ, dvipadacatuppadehi vaḍḍheyyuṃ, puttadārehi vaḍḍheyyuṃ, dāsakammakaraporisehi vaḍḍheyyuṃ, ñātīhi vaḍḍheyyuṃ, mittehi vaḍḍheyyuṃ, bandhavehi vaḍḍheyyun’ti.
dn30:2.4.3.eng: ‘How might they flourish in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, teachings, and wisdom; in wealth and grain, fields and land, birds and beasts, children and partners; in bondservants, workers, and staff; in family, friends, and kin?’

dn30:2.4.4.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.4.5.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni tīṇi mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:2.4.5.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these three marks:

dn30:2.4.6.pli: Sīhapubbaddhakāyo ca hoti citantaraṃso ca samavaṭṭakkhandho ca.
dn30:2.4.6.eng: his chest is like that of a lion; he is filled out between the shoulders.; and his torso is cylindrical.
dn30:2.4.6.comm: A khema is a sanctuary where animals flourish in peace, without fear of the hunter. Likewise, the Buddha’s body flourishes and has a fullness to it. He is slim but not skinny.

dn30:2.5.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.5.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.5.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.5.3.pli: Aparihānadhammo hoti, na parihāyati dhanadhaññena khettavatthunā dvipadacatuppadehi puttadārehi dāsakammakaraporisehi ñātīhi mittehi bandhavehi, na parihāyati sabbasampattiyā.
dn30:2.5.3.eng: He’s not liable to decline. He doesn’t decline in wealth and grain, fields and land, birds and beasts, children and partners; in bondservants, workers, and staff; in family, friends, and kin. He doesn’t decline in any of his accomplishments.

dn30:2.5.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.5.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.5.6.pli: Aparihānadhammo hoti, na parihāyati saddhāya sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya, na parihāyati sabbasampattiyā.
dn30:2.5.6.eng: He’s not liable to decline. He doesn’t decline in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. He doesn’t decline in any of his accomplishments.
dn30:2.5.6.comm: Decline in dhamma is missing here, but present both above and below in verse.

dn30:2.5.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.6.2.eng: “His wish was this: ‘How may others not decline

dn30:2.6.3.eng: in faith, ethics, learning, and intelligence,

dn30:2.6.4.eng: in generosity, teachings, and much good else,

dn30:2.6.5.eng: in coin and grain, fields and lands,

dn30:2.6.8.eng: in strength, and both beauty and happiness?’

dn30:2.6.9.eng: And so he ever desired their success.

dn30:2.6.10.eng: His chest was shaped like that of a lion,

dn30:2.6.11.eng: filled out between the shoulders, <j>and torso cylindrical.

dn30:2.6.12.eng: Due to the well-done deeds of the past,

dn30:2.6.13.eng: he had that portent of non-decline.

dn30:2.6.14.eng: Even as layman he grows in coin and grain,

dn30:2.6.16.eng: But once gone forth, owning nothing, he attains

dn30:2.6.17.eng: the supreme awakening which may never decline.”

dn30:2.7.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.7.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.7.2.pli: sattānaṃ aviheṭhakajātiko ahosi pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā satthena vā.
dn30:2.7.2.eng: He would never hurt any sentient being with fists, stones, rods, or swords.

dn30:2.7.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.7.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati, rasaggasaggī hoti, uddhaggāssa rasaharaṇīyo gīvāya jātā honti samābhivāhiniyo.
dn30:2.7.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark: he has ridged taste buds. His raised taste receptors, originating in the throat, disperse evenly.

dn30:2.8.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.8.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.8.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.8.3.pli: Appābādho hoti appātaṅko, samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya.
dn30:2.8.3.eng: He is rarely ill or unwell. His stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold.
dn30:2.8.3.comm: The “ridged taste buds” are not merely for tasting, but support excellent digestion. Kammically, the rationale is that since he did not kill others, now nothing hurts him when he eats.

dn30:2.8.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.8.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.8.6.pli: Appābādho hoti appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya.
dn30:2.8.6.eng: He is rarely ill or unwell. His stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

dn30:2.8.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.9.2.eng: “Not with fist or rod or stone,

dn30:2.9.3.eng: or sword or beating to death,

dn30:2.9.6.eng: For that very reason he rejoiced in heaven <j>after passing away,

dn30:2.9.7.eng: finding happiness as a fruit of happy deeds.

dn30:2.9.8.eng: With taste receptors prominent <j>and evenly spreading nutrition,

dn30:2.9.9.eng: on his return here he has ridged taste buds.

dn30:2.9.10.eng: That’s why the clever prophets said:

dn30:2.9.13.eng: That’s the meaning shown by this mark.’”

dn30:2.10.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.10.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.10.2.pli: na ca visaṭaṃ, na ca visāci, na ca pana viceyya pekkhitā, ujuṃ tathā pasaṭamujumano, piyacakkhunā bahujanaṃ udikkhitā ahosi.
dn30:2.10.2.eng: When looking at others he didn’t glare, look askance, or avert his eyes. Being straightforward, he reached out to others with straightforward intentions, looking at people with kindly eyes.

dn30:2.10.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.10.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:2.10.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:

dn30:2.10.5.eng: his eyes are indigo, and he has eyelashes like a cow’s.
dn30:2.10.5.comm: Dark colored eyes give the impression of wide pupils and an open gaze, while the eyelashes of cows lend them a tenderness.

dn30:2.11.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato, sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.11.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.11.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.11.3.pli: Piyadassano hoti bahuno janassa, piyo hoti manāpo brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṃ negamajānapadānaṃ gaṇakamahāmattānaṃ anīkaṭṭhānaṃ dovārikānaṃ amaccānaṃ pārisajjānaṃ rājūnaṃ bhogiyānaṃ kumārānaṃ.
dn30:2.11.3.eng: The people look on him with kindly eyes. He is dear and beloved to the brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

dn30:2.11.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.11.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.11.6.pli: Piyadassano hoti bahuno janassa, piyo hoti manāpo bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ devānaṃ manussānaṃ asurānaṃ nāgānaṃ gandhabbānaṃ.
dn30:2.11.6.eng: The people look on him with kindly eyes. He is dear and beloved to the monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:2.11.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.12.2.eng: “With not a glare or glance askance,

dn30:2.12.5.eng: looking at people with kindly eyes.

dn30:2.12.6.eng: In good rebirths he enjoyed the fruit

dn30:2.12.8.eng: But here he has a cow’s eyelashes,

dn30:2.12.9.eng: and indigo eyes so fair to see.

dn30:2.12.10.comm: Abhiyogino (“soothsayers”) is a unique term, explained by the commentary, “they are dedicated to the lore of marks”.

dn30:2.12.13.eng: he’d be looked upon with kindly eyes.

dn30:2.12.14.eng: Even as a householder he’d be regarded kindly,

dn30:2.12.16.pli: Yadi ca na bhavati gihī samaṇo hoti,
dn30:2.12.16.eng: But if he becomes an ascetic, not lay,

dn30:2.12.17.eng: as destroyer of sorrow he’ll be loved by many.”

dn30:2.13.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.13.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.13.2.pli: bahujanapubbaṅgamo ahosi kusalesu dhammesu bahujanapāmokkho kāyasucarite vacīsucarite manosucarite dānasaṃvibhāge sīlasamādāne uposathupavāse matteyyatāya petteyyatāya sāmaññatāya brahmaññatāya kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitāya aññataraññataresu ca adhikusalesu dhammesu.
dn30:2.13.2.eng: He was the leader and forerunner of people in skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.
dn30:2.13.2.comm: The commentary says he took the lead in good deeds “unembarrassed, with head held high, his head filled with rapture and joy”.

dn30:2.13.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.13.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati—
dn30:2.13.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:

dn30:2.13.5.eng: the crown of his head is like a turban.

dn30:2.14.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.14.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.14.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.14.3.pli: Mahāssa jano anvāyiko hoti, brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
dn30:2.14.3.eng: He has a large following of brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

dn30:2.14.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.14.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.14.6.pli: Mahāssa jano anvāyiko hoti, bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā.
dn30:2.14.6.eng: He has a large following of monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:2.14.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.15.2.eng: “Among people of good conduct, he was the leader,

dn30:2.15.3.eng: devoted to a life of principle among the principled.

dn30:2.15.5.eng: and he experienced the fruit of good deeds in heaven.

dn30:2.15.7.eng: he gains a head crowned like a turban.

dn30:2.15.8.eng: The experts in omens and signs prophesied:

dn30:2.15.9.eng: ‘He will be leader of the people.

dn30:2.15.11.eng: they will bring presents for him.

dn30:2.15.12.eng: If he becomes an aristocrat, ruler of the land,

dn30:2.15.13.eng: he’ll gain the service of the people.

dn30:2.15.14.eng: But if that man goes forth,

dn30:2.15.15.eng: he’ll be sophisticated, proficient in the teachings.

dn30:2.15.16.eng: Devoted to the virtues of his instruction,

dn30:2.15.17.eng: the people will become his followers.’”

dn30:2.16.0.eng: 24–25. One Hair Per Pore, and a Tuft

dn30:2.16.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.16.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.16.2.pli: musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato ahosi, saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa.
dn30:2.16.2.eng: He refrained from lying. He spoke the truth and stuck to the truth. He was honest and dependable, and didn’t trick the world with his words.

dn30:2.16.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.16.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:2.16.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:

dn30:2.16.5.pli: Ekekalomo ca hoti, uṇṇā ca bhamukantare jātā hoti odātā mudutūlasannibhā.
dn30:2.16.5.eng: his hairs grow one per pore, and between his eyebrows there grows a tuft, soft and white like cotton-wool.
dn30:2.16.5.comm: One hair per pore, because his words of truth have only one meaning. Likewise, the tuft conveys purity and integrity.

dn30:2.17.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato, sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.17.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.17.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.17.3.pli: Mahāssa jano upavattati, brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
dn30:2.17.3.eng: He has many close adherents among the brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

dn30:2.17.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.17.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.17.6.pli: Mahāssa jano upavattati, bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā.
dn30:2.17.6.eng: He has many close adherents among the monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:2.17.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.18.2.eng: “In past lives he was true to his promise,

dn30:2.18.3.eng: with no forked tongue, he shunned lies.

dn30:2.18.4.eng: He never broke his word to anyone,

dn30:2.18.5.eng: but spoke what was true, real, and factual.

dn30:2.18.6.eng: A tuft so very white like cotton-wool

dn30:2.18.8.eng: And never two, but only one,

dn30:2.18.9.eng: hair grew in each of his pores.

dn30:2.18.11.eng: and expert in signs gathered and prophesied:

dn30:2.18.12.pli: Uṇṇā ca lomā ca yathā susaṇṭhitā,
dn30:2.18.12.eng: ‘One like this, with tuft and hair so prominent,

dn30:2.18.13.eng: will have many as his close adherents.

dn30:2.18.14.eng: Even as householder many people will follow him,

dn30:2.18.15.eng: due to the power of deeds in the past.

dn30:2.18.16.eng: But once gone forth, owning nothing,

dn30:2.18.17.eng: as Buddha the people will follow him.’”

dn30:2.19.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.19.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.19.2.pli: pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato ahosi. Ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya, iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā ahosi.
dn30:2.19.2.eng: He refrained from divisive speech. He didn’t repeat in one place what he heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, he reconciled those who were divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

dn30:2.19.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.19.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:2.19.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:

dn30:2.19.5.eng: he has forty teeth, and his teeth have no gaps.
dn30:2.19.5.comm: The number four connotes “all around, complete, universal”, primarily from the four directions. It is multiplied to eight with the intermediate directions, and ten including above and below. Forty, then, is four times ten, a number of super-inclusiveness or super-universality. The lack of gaps corresponds with the lack of division between his followers.

dn30:2.20.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.20.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.20.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.20.3.pli: Abhejjapariso hoti, abhejjāssa honti parisā, brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
dn30:2.20.3.eng: His retinue cannot be divided. This includes brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

dn30:2.20.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.20.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.20.6.pli: Abhejjapariso hoti, abhejjāssa honti parisā, bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā.
dn30:2.20.6.eng: His retinue cannot be divided. This includes monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:2.20.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.22.0.eng: 28–29. A Large Tongue and the Voice of the Divinity

dn30:2.22.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.22.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.22.2.pli: pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato ahosi. Yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā, tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā ahosi.
dn30:2.22.2.eng: He refrained from harsh speech. He spoke in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

dn30:2.22.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.22.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati.
dn30:2.22.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks:

dn30:2.22.5.pli: Pahūtajivho ca hoti brahmassaro ca karavīkabhāṇī.
dn30:2.22.5.eng: he has a large tongue, and the voice of the Divinity, like a cuckoo’s call.

dn30:2.23.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.23.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.23.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.23.3.pli: Ādeyyavāco hoti, ādiyantissa vacanaṃ brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
dn30:2.23.3.eng: He has a compelling voice. His words are compelling to brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

dn30:2.23.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.23.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.23.6.pli: Ādeyyavāco hoti, ādiyantissa vacanaṃ bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā.
dn30:2.23.6.eng: He has a compelling voice. His words are compelling to monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:2.23.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.24.2.eng: “He never spoke a loud harsh word,

dn30:2.24.4.eng: causing harm, rude, crushing the people.

dn30:2.24.5.eng: His speech was sweet, helpful, and courteous.

dn30:2.24.6.eng: He uttered words dear to the mind,

dn30:2.24.7.eng: going to the heart, pleasing to the ear.

dn30:2.24.8.eng: He enjoyed the fruit of his good verbal conduct,

dn30:2.24.12.eng: His tongue was long and wide,

dn30:2.24.15.eng: But if that man goes forth,

dn30:2.25.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.25.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.25.2.pli: samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato ahosi kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā ahosi kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ.
dn30:2.25.2.eng: He refrained from talking nonsense. His words were timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. He said things at the right time which were valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

dn30:2.25.3.eng: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.25.4.pli: so tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ paṭilabhati,
dn30:2.25.4.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained this mark:

dn30:2.25.5.eng: his jaw is like that of a lion.
dn30:2.25.5.comm: The commentary explains that those who flap their mouths with nonsensical gossip end up with weak or misshapen jaws.

dn30:2.26.1.pli: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
dn30:2.26.1.eng: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

dn30:2.26.2.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.26.3.pli: Appadhaṃsiyo hoti kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena paccāmittena.
dn30:2.26.3.eng: He can’t be destroyed by any human foe or enemy.

dn30:2.26.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.26.5.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.26.6.pli: Appadhaṃsiyo hoti abbhantarehi vā bāhirehi vā paccatthikehi paccāmittehi, rāgena vā dosena vā mohena vā samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
dn30:2.26.6.eng: He can’t be destroyed by any foe or enemy whether internal or external; nor by greed, hate, or delusion; nor by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

dn30:2.26.7.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”

dn30:2.27.4.eng: He cast aside what was unbeneficial,

dn30:2.27.10.eng: He became a king so very hard to defeat,

dn30:2.28.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṃ jātiṃ purimaṃ bhavaṃ purimaṃ niketaṃ pubbe manussabhūto samāno
dn30:2.28.1.eng: “Mendicants, in some past lives the Realized One was reborn as a human being.

dn30:2.28.2.pli: micchājīvaṃ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappesi, tulākūṭakaṃsakūṭamānakūṭaukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogachedanavadhabandhanaviparāmosaālopasahasākārā paṭivirato ahosi.
dn30:2.28.2.eng: He gave up wrong livelihood and earned a living by right livelihood. He refrained from falsifying weights, metals, or measures; bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

dn30:2.28.3.pli: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
dn30:2.28.3.eng: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn30:2.28.4.pli: So tattha aññe deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti dibbena āyunā dibbena vaṇṇena dibbena sukhena dibbena yasena dibbena ādhipateyyena dibbehi rūpehi dibbehi saddehi dibbehi gandhehi dibbehi rasehi dibbehi phoṭṭhabbehi.
dn30:2.28.4.eng: There he surpassed the other gods in ten respects: heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

dn30:2.28.5.pli: So tato cuto itthattaṃ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati, samadanto ca hoti susukkadāṭho ca.
dn30:2.28.5.eng: When he came back to this place he obtained these two marks: his teeth are even and perfectly white.
dn30:2.28.5.comm: His teeth are not “crooked” or “stained” by corruption.

dn30:2.29.1.pli: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
dn30:2.29.1.eng: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.

dn30:2.29.2.eng: He has the following seven treasures:

dn30:2.29.3.pli: cakkaratanaṃ hatthiratanaṃ assaratanaṃ maṇiratanaṃ itthiratanaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.
dn30:2.29.3.eng: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.

dn30:2.29.4.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
dn30:2.29.4.eng: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

dn30:2.29.5.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṃ iddhaṃ phītaṃ khemaṃ sivaṃ nirabbudaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
dn30:2.29.5.eng: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, and free of pests—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

dn30:2.29.6.eng: And what does he obtain as king?

dn30:2.29.7.pli: Suciparivāro hoti sucissa honti parivārā brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
dn30:2.29.7.eng: His retinue is pure. This includes brahmins and householders, people of town and country, finance ministers, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, councillors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

dn30:2.29.8.eng: That’s what he obtains as king.

dn30:2.30.1.pli: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati, arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
dn30:2.30.1.eng: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who has cast off the world’s veil.

dn30:2.30.2.eng: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

dn30:2.30.3.pli: Suciparivāro hoti, sucissa honti parivārā, bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā.
dn30:2.30.3.eng: His retinue is pure. This includes monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, gods, humans, titans, dragons, and centaurs.

dn30:2.30.4.eng: That’s what he obtains as Buddha.”
